I created a document that dives into details and benchmarks around Merkle Patricia Tries and Verkle Tries, mostly around moving from Keccack to Pedersen Commitments.
Tries to cover both the theoretical angle, but also having real numbers about the overhead by benchmarking current Go implementations to be used in geth.

author: jsign
content:
Yep, actually it dives into some details about what that question really means apart from "raw" numbers. 
For example, I tried to come up with amortized cost "per value" for Pedersen Commitments to have a fair comparison with Keccak. (Since PC are vector commitments, not single value ones).
So apart from the amortized cost, the remaining questions are about to come up with a reasonable assumption about how many "values" on average land on the same leaf, since the cost is linear to the non-zero values.
But that only is entirely relevant for new leaves. For updating leaves, there's another trick used by the implementation (if I connected correctly reading the code and my theoretical knowledge) that changes things a bit.
(The EIP to map account state values to addresses in the trie is mixed in the scene too)

Anyway, hopefully all this better explained there. But yeah, tried to answer that question <@427491045308235776> ! üòÖ
